## HW1

### Problem 1: 
In a home economic experiment, two temperatures (factor A) and two lengths of washing time (factor B) gave the following treatment means. The experiment was conducted as a completely randomized design with n=5 for teach treatment combination. The variable of interest was the amount of impurities (in grams) remaining in the material washed. Assume fixed effects for both factors.

```{r echo=FALSE}
library(kableExtra)
Factor <- c("(1)","a","b","ab")
Mean <- c(6.2,14.1,5.4,7.8)
kable(t(data.frame(Factor,Mean)))%>%kable_styling("condensed",full_width = F, position = "center")
```

<!--|     |(1) |a	  |b	 |ab
| --- | -- | -- | -- | --
|Mean	|6.2 |14.1|5.4 |7.8-->

(i) Compute the numerical values of the following effects and interpret in terms of question context:

a. main effect of A

$A=\frac12(-\bar y_{(1)}+\bar y_a-\bar y_b+\bar y_{ab})=\frac12(-6.2+14.1-5.4+7.8)=5.15$

The average amount of impurities remaining in the material washed increase by 5.15 grams as the temperatures changes from low to high. 

b. main effect of B

$B=\frac12(-\bar y_{(1)}-\bar y_a+\bar y_b+\bar y_{ab})=\frac12(-6.2-14.1+5.4+7.8)=-3.55$

The average amount of impurities remaining in the material washed decrease by 3.55 grams as the lengths of washing time changes from short to long. 

c. interaction effect of A and B
	
$AB=\frac12(\bar y_{(1)}-\bar y_a-\bar y_b+\bar y_{ab})=\frac12(6.2-14.1-5.4+7.8)=-2.75$

The change in average amount of impurities remaining in the material washed when the temperatures changes from low to high at long wsahing time is smaller by 2.75 grams than short washing time. 

(ii) Explain which effect is highest from the effects in part (i).

The main effect of A is highest and main effect of B is smaller than that while it is higher than interaction effect.

(iii) Compute the sum of square for each effect in part (i).

$SS_A=\frac{n}4C_A^2=\frac{n}4(-\bar y_{(1)}+\bar y_a-\bar y_b+\bar y_{ab})^2=\frac54(-6.2+14.1-5.4+7.8)^2=132.6125$

$SS_B=\frac{n}4C_B^2=\frac{n}4(-\bar y_{(1)}-\bar y_a+\bar y_b+\bar y_{ab})^2=\frac54(-6.2-14.1+5.4+7.8)^2=63.0125$

$SS_{AB}=\frac{n}4C_{AB}^2=\frac{n}4(\bar y_{(1)}-\bar y_a-\bar y_b+\bar y_{ab})^2=\frac54(6.2-14.1-5.4+7.8)^2=37.8125$

```{r eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}

29.8*16+132.6125+63.0125+37.8125
```

(iv) If the MSE = 29.8, then compute all the terms of the ANOVA table for this study.

|Source of Variation|   SS          |      df      | MS     | F      |P-value   |
|         ---       |   ---         |   ---        | ---    | ---    | ---      |
|Factor A           |132.6125       |   $2-1=1$    |132.6125|$\frac{132.6125}{29.8}=4.450084$|0.0510038 |
|Factor B           | 63.0125       |   $2-1=1$    | 63.0125|$\frac{63.0125}{29.8}=2.114513$|0.1652436 |
|Interaction AB     | 37.8125       |$(2-1)(2-1)=1$| 37.8125|$\frac{37.8125}{29.8}=1.268876$|0.2765897 |
|Error              |$29.8*16=476.8$|$4*(5-1)=16$  | 29.8   |
|     |$132.6125+63.0125+37.8125$|
|Total|$+476.8=710.2375$|$2^2*5-1=19$  |

(v) Based on your ANOVA table, explain which of effects in part (i) are statistically significant at 5% significance level.

Based on the ANOVA table, all the P-value are larger than 0.05. There is no factor has significant effects at 5% significance level.

### Problem 3:

Consider the single replicated $2^3$ factorial design with ABC confounded with two blocks.
Prove algebraically the $SS_{ABC}=SS_{Block}$ (see the example did in class for $2^2$ design)

Factor ABC is confounded with two blocks, $p=1$. Each block have 4 observations. The ABC interaction is defined as the average difference between the BC interaction at the two different levels of A.

$SS_{ABC}=\sum_i^2\sum_j^2\sum_k^2(\hat\tau\hat\beta\hat\gamma)_{ijk}^2=2^3(\frac{-y_{111}+y_{211}+y_{121}-y_{221}+y_{112}-y_{212}-y_{122}+y_{222}}{2^3})^2$

$$=\frac1{2^3}(-y_{(1)}+ y_{a}+y_{b}- y_{ab}+ y_{c}- y_{ac}- y_{bc}+ y_{abc})^2=\frac{1}{2^3}C_{ABC}^2$$

$SS_{Block}=\sum_i^2\sum_j^2\sum_k^2\sum_l^2\hat\delta_l^2=2^2(\delta_1^2+\delta_2^2)=2^2[(\bar y_{blk1}-\bar y_{...})^2+(\bar y_{blk2}-\bar y_{...})^2]$

$\bar y_{blk1}-\bar y_{...}=\frac{1}{4}[y_{(1)}+y_{ab}+y_{ac}+y_{bc}]-\bar y_{...}=\frac{1}{4}[y_{111}+y_{221}+y_{212}+y_{122}]-\frac{1}{8}[y_{111}+y_{211}+y_{121}+y_{221}+y_{112}+y_{212}+y_{122}+y_{222}]$

$=\frac{1}{8}[y_{111}-y_{211}-y_{121}+y_{221}-y_{112}+y_{212}+y_{122}-y_{222}]=\frac18[y_{(1)}-y_{a}-y_{b}+y_{ab}-y_{c}+ y_{ac}+y_{bc}-y_{abc}]=-\frac18C_{ABC}$

By the same way, $\bar y_{blk2}-\bar y_{...}=\frac18C_{ABC}$. Therefore,

$$SS_{Block}=2^2[(-\frac18C_{ABC})^2+(\frac18C_{ABC})^2]=\frac1{2^3}C_{ABC}^2=SS_{ABC}$$

## HW3

### Problem 1:
A manufacturer suspects that the batches of raw material furnished by his supplier differ significantly in calcium content. There are a large number of batches currently in the warehouse. Five of these are randomly selected for study. A chemist makes four determinations on each batch and obtains the following numerical summaries of data:

Batch	1	2	3	4	5
Mean	23.458	23.492	23.524	23.380	23.364
Variance	0.005	0.004	0.005	0.004	0.004

(a) Write the complete model you fit for these data.

$$y_{ij}=\mu+\tau_i+\varepsilon_{ij}$$

for $i=1,2,3,4,5$ is the number of treatment being compared; 

$j=1,2,3,4$ is the number of replications for each treatment; 

$y_{ij}$ is response value for the $j^{th}$ replication when $i^{th}$ treatment is applied;

$\mu$ is the overall true mean response;

$\tau_i$ is the random effect of $i^{th}$ treatment (batches);

$\varepsilon_{ij}$ is random error for the $j^{th}$ replication when $i^{th}$ treatment is applied;

Assumptions: $\varepsilon_{ij}\sim iid N(0,\sigma^2)$; $\tau_{i}\sim iid N(0,\sigma_\tau^2)$; $\varepsilon_{ij}$ and $\tau_{i}$ are independent.

(b) Compute the SSE for the ANOVA of the model.

$$SSE=(n-1)\sum_{i=1}^5S_i^2=(4-1)(0.005+0.004+0.005+0.004+0.004)=0.066$$

(c) Compute the estimated error variance and a 95% confidence interval for the true error variance.

$$\hat\sigma^2=MSE=SSE/(N-a)=0.066/(20-5)=0.0044$$

$$\frac{SSE}{\chi^2_{\alpha/2,df_E=15}}=0.066/27.48839=0.002401014\qquad \frac{SSE}{\chi^2_{1-\alpha/2,df_E=15}}=0.066/6.262138=0.01053953$$

The 95% confidence interval for the true error variance is $[0.002401014,0.01053953]$


(d)  Compute the estimated variance of batches of raw material.

$\bar y_{..}=(23.458+23.492+23.524+23.380+23.364)/5=23.4436$

$MS_{Trt}=4\sum_{i=1}^5(\bar y_{i.}-\bar y_{..})^2/(a-1)=$
$4[(23.458-23.4436)^2+(23.492-23.4436)^2+(23.524-23.4436)^2+(23.380-23.4436)^2+(23.364-23.4436)^2]/4=0.0193952$

$$\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2=(MS_{Trt}-MSE)/n=(0.0193952-0.0044)/4=0.0037488$$

(e) Compute the estimated value for proportion of variance in the response explained by the different batches of raw material.

$$\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2/(\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2+\hat\sigma^2)=(0.0037488)/(0.0037488+0.0044)=0.4600432$$

(f) Compute a 99% confidence interval for the true proportion of variance in the response explained by the different batches of raw material.

$\frac{MS_{Trt}}{MS_E}\cdot\frac{\hat\sigma^2}{n\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2+\hat\sigma^2}\sim F_{a-1,N-a}$

$$P\left[F_{1-\alpha/2}<\frac{MS_{Trt}}{MS_E}\cdot\frac{\sigma^2}{n\sigma_{\tau}^2+\sigma^2}<F_{\alpha/2}\right]=1-\alpha$$

$100(1-\alpha)\%=99\%$, $\alpha=0.01$, then the Lower bound and Uper bound for $\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2/\hat\sigma^2$ are

$L=\frac1n\left(\frac{MS_{Trt}}{MS_EF_{\alpha/2}}-1\right)=\frac14\left(\frac{0.0193952}{0.0044*5.802907}-1\right)=-0.06009518$

$U=\frac1n\left(\frac{MS_{Trt}}{MS_EF_{1-\alpha/2}}-1\right)=\frac14\left(\frac{0.0193952}{0.0044*0.04892783}-1\right)=22.27297$

 $$\frac{L}{1+L}=\frac{-0.06009518}{1-0.06009518}=-0.06393752,\quad\frac{U}{1+U}=\frac{22.27297}{1+22.27297}=0.9570317$$

 99% confidence interal for $\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2/(\hat\sigma_{\tau}^2+\hat\sigma^2)$ is $[0,0.9570317]$

### Problem 2:

Find the E(SSAB) for the two-way ANOVA model (or two-factor model) when both factors have random effects.

$$E(SS_{AB})=E[\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n(\widehat{\tau\beta})_{ij}^2]=\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^nE[(\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...})^2]$$

$y_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_{i}+\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{ij.}=\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_{i}+\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{i..}=\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_{i}+\frac1b {\sum_{j=1}^b[\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}]}+\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{.j.}=\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\beta_j+\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a[\tau_i+(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{...}=\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a\tau_i+\frac1b\sum_{j=1}^b\beta_j+\frac1{ab}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$$\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i.}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}=(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1b \sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{ab}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}$$
$$+\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$$

 ---

Let $W=(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1b \sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{ab}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}$

$Z=\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

For $\varepsilon_{ijk}\sim iid N(0,\sigma^2)$, $(\tau\beta)_{ij}\sim iid N(0,\sigma^2_{\tau\beta})$

$$Var[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]=Var[W+Z]=Var[W]+Var[Z]+Cov[W,Z]$$

 ---

$$Var[W]=Var[(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1b \sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{ab}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]$$

$$=Var[(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{a^2}\sum_{i=1}^aVar[(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{b^2} \sum_{j=1}^bVar[(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{a^2b^2}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^bVar[(\tau\beta)_{ij}]$$

$$-\frac2{a}Cov[(\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}]-\frac2{b}Cov[(\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac2{ab}Cov[(\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]$$

$$+\frac2{ab}Cov[(\sum_{i=1}^a\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]-\frac2{a^2b}Cov[\sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]-\frac2{ab^2}Cov[\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]$$

$$=\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}+\frac{\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{a}+\frac{\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{b}+\frac{\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}-\frac{2\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{a}-\frac{2\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{b}+\frac{2\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}+\frac{2\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}-\frac{2\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}-\frac{2\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}$$

 ---

$$Var[Z]=Var[\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$=\frac1{n^2}\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{1}{a^2n^2}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{1}{b^2n^2}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{1}{a^2b^2n^2}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$-\frac{2}{an^2}Cov[\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]-\frac{2}{bn^2}Cov[\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{2}{abn^2}Cov[\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$+\frac{2}{abn^2}Cov[\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]-\frac{2}{a^2bn^2}Cov[\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]-\frac{2}{ab^2n^2}Cov[\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$=\frac1n\sigma^2+\frac{\sigma^2}{an}+\frac{\sigma^2}{bn}+\frac{\sigma^2}{abn}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{an}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{bn}+\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}+\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2}{abn}$$

 ---

For $\varepsilon_{ijk}$ and $(\tau\beta)_{ij}$ are independent and are the only variable in $W$ and $Z$ corresponsively, $Cov[W,Z]=0$, then

$$Var[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}+\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2}{abn}=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)(n\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}+\sigma^2)}{abn}$$

For $E[(\widehat{\tau\beta})_{ij}]=0$

$$E(SS_{AB})=\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^nE[(\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...})^2]=\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\left\{Var[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]+E[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]^2\right\}$$

$$=\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\frac{(a-1)(b-1)(n\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}+\sigma^2)}{abn}=(a-1)(b-1)(\sigma^2+n\sigma^2_{\tau\beta})$$

### Problem 4

Consider the two-factor restricted mixed model with A has fixed effect and B has random effect given below.

$y_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_i+\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\varepsilon_{ijk}$,
$i=1,2..,a$; $j=1,2,..,b$; $k=1,2,..,n$; 

Assumptions: 

$\varepsilon_{ijk}\sim iid N(0,\sigma^2)$; $\sum_{i=1}^a\tau_{i}=0$; $\sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}=0$ (restricted model); $\beta_{j}\sim iid N(0,\sigma_\beta^2)$; 
$(\tau\beta)_{ij}\sim iid N(0,\sigma_{\tau\beta}^2)$;
$\varepsilon_{ijk}$, $\beta_{j}$, and $(\tau\beta)_{ij}$ are independent.

Derive the E(SSAB) for this model using only the given information here.

$$E(SS_{AB})=E[\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n(\widehat{\tau\beta})_{ij}^2]=n\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^bE[(\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...})^2]$$

$y_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_{i}+\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{ij.}=\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_{i}+\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{i..}=\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\tau_{i}+\frac1b {\sum_{j=1}^b[\beta_j+(\tau\beta)_{ij}]}+\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

For $\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a\tau_i=0, \quad\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}=0$

$\bar y_{.j.}=\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\beta_j+\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a[\tau_i+(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}=\mu+\beta_j+\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$\bar y_{...}=\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^ny_{ijk}=\mu+\frac1a \sum_{i=1}^a\tau_i+\frac1b\sum_{j=1}^b\beta_j+\frac1{ab}\sum_{j=1}^b[\sum_{i=1}^a(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$
$=\mu+\frac1b\sum_{j=1}^b\beta_j+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

$$\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i.}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}=(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1b \sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}+\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$$

 ---

Let $W=(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1b \sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}$

$Z=\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}$

For $\varepsilon_{ijk}\sim iid N(0,\sigma^2)$, $(\tau\beta)_{ij}\sim iid N(0,\frac{a-1}{a}\sigma^2_{\tau\beta})$

$$Var[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]=Var[W+Z]=Var[W]+Var[Z]+Cov[W,Z]$$

 ---

$Var[W]=Var[(\tau\beta)_{ij}-\frac1b \sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]=Var[(\tau\beta)_{ij}]+\frac1{b^2} \sum_{j=1}^bVar[(\tau\beta)_{ij}]-\frac2{b}Cov[(\tau\beta)_{ij},\sum_{j=1}^b(\tau\beta)_{ij}]$


$$=\frac{a-1}{a}\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}(1-\frac{1}{b})=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}$$

 ---

$$Var[Z]=Var[\frac1{n}\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{an}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}-\frac1{bn}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}+\frac1{abn}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$=\frac1{n^2}\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{1}{a^2n^2}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{1}{b^2n^2}\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{1}{a^2b^2n^2}\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^nVar[\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$-\frac{2}{an^2}Cov[\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]-\frac{2}{bn^2}Cov[\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]+\frac{2}{abn^2}Cov[\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$+\frac{2}{abn^2}Cov[\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]-\frac{2}{a^2bn^2}Cov[\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]-\frac{2}{ab^2n^2}Cov[\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk},\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\sum_{k=1}^n\varepsilon_{ijk}]$$

$$=\frac1n\sigma^2+\frac{\sigma^2}{an}+\frac{\sigma^2}{bn}+\frac{\sigma^2}{abn}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{an}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{bn}+\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}+\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}-\frac{2\sigma^2}{abn}=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2}{abn}$$

 ---

For $\varepsilon_{ijk}$ and $(\tau\beta)_{ij}$ are independent and are the only variable in $W$ and $Z$ corresponsively, $Cov[W,Z]=0$, then

$$Var[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}}{ab}+\frac{(a-1)(b-1)\sigma^2}{abn}=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)(n\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}+\sigma^2)}{abn}$$

For $(\tau\beta)_{ij}\sim iid N(0,\frac{a-1}{a}\sigma^2_{\tau\beta})$, $E[(\widehat{\tau\beta})_{ij}]=0$

$$E(SS_{AB})=n\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^bE[(\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...})^2]=n\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\left\{Var[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]+E[\bar y_{ij.}-\bar y_{i..}-\bar y_{.j.}+\bar y_{...}]^2\right\}$$

$$=n\sum_{i=1}^a\sum_{j=1}^b\frac{(a-1)(b-1)(n\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}+\sigma^2)}{abn}=(a-1)(b-1)(n\sigma^2_{\tau\beta}+\sigma^2)$$
